title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SACRAMENTO – On a night destined to be remembered for one man’s singular brilliance, Glen Rice delivered a performance for the ages, carrying the Charlotte Hornets to a gritty 97-93 road victory over the Sacramento Kings in 1997.

Rice was simply unguardable, erupting for a career-high and franchise-record 48 points. From the opening tip, the Hornets’ offense flowed through their sharpshooting forward, who put on a masterclass in scoring efficiency. He shot a blistering 16-of-23 from the field, including a remarkable 7-of-11 from beyond the arc, and was a perfect 9-for-9 from the free-throw line. His explosive output was the sole engine of the Hornets' attack, as no other teammate scored more than Vlade Divac's 12 points.

The Kings, led by Mitch Richmond’s 28 points and Corliss Williamson’s 20, fought valiantly to keep pace. They traded blows with the Hornets throughout a tense second half, but they had no answer for Rice’s relentless onslaught. Every time Sacramento threatened to seize momentum, Rice responded with a dagger three or a clutch basket to quiet the home crowd.

In the game's final, breathless minutes, it was Rice who iced the victory. With the outcome still hanging in the balance, he calmly sank his free throws, securing both the win and his place in the record books. This was not merely a win; it was a historic night defined by one man’s transcendent talent, a 48-point explosion that will forever be etched in Charlotte Hornets lore.
